HOP.NAME: Centennial
HOP.NOTES: Medium with floral and citrus tones.

HOP.NAME: Mount Hood
HOP.NOTES: Mild, pleasant, clean, light, and delicate.

HOP.NAME: Willamette
HOP.NOTES: mild and pleasant, slightly spicy, aromatic.

YEAST.NAME: Wyeast - Northwest Ale
YEAST.NOTES: One of the classic ale strains from a Northwest US Brewery. Produces malty and mildly fruity ale with a good depth and complexity.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Any American Ale, Blonde Ale, Spiced/Herb/Vegetable Ale, Fruit Ale

RECIPE.NAME: American IPA - SN Celebration Ale

STYLE.NAME: American IPA
STYLE.NOTES: 2007 Maltose Falcons Mayfaire - 2nd Runnerup BOS 2008 AHA NHC West Region First Round - 1st Place 2008 AHA NHC Second Round - 3rd Place

WATER.NAME: Burton on Trent, UK
WATER.NOTES: Use for distinctive pale ales strongly hopped. Very hard water accentuates the hops flavor. Example: Bass Ale

RECIPE.TASTE_NOTES: Based on Sierra Nevada's 1999 Celebration Ale

HOP.NAME: Northern Brewer
HOP.NOTES: Medium-strong, woody with evergreen and mint overtones.

YEAST.NAME: Wyeast - American Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Very clean, crisp flavor characteristics. Low fruitiness and mild ester production. Slightly citrus-like with cool (15-19C) fermentation. Versatile yeast, which produces many beer styles allowing malt and hop character to dominate the beer profile. Flocculation improves with dark malts in grain bill. Normally requires filtration for bright beers.

HOP.NAME: Sterling
HOP.NOTES: Flavor: cross between Saaz and Mt. Hood.Aroma: herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus notes.

HOP.NAME: Northern Brewer
HOP.NOTES: Medium-strong, woody with evergreen and mint overtones.

HOP.NAME: Sterling
HOP.NOTES: Flavor: cross between Saaz and Mt. Hood.Aroma: herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus notes.

HOP.NAME: Sterling
HOP.NOTES: Flavor: cross between Saaz and Mt. Hood.Aroma: herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus notes.

YEAST.NAME: Wyeast - Thames Valley Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Produces classic British bitters, rich complex flavor profile, clean, light malt character, low fruitiness, low esters, well balanced.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Ordinary/Special Bitter, ESB, Northern English Brown, Robust Porter, Dry Stout, Foreign Extra Stout

HOP.NAME: Northern Brewer
HOP.NOTES: Medium-strong, woody with evergreen and mint overtones.

HOP.NAME: Northern Brewer
HOP.NOTES: Medium-strong, woody with evergreen and mint overtones.

YEAST.NAME: Wyeast - American Ale II
YEAST.NOTES: Consistent performance. Fruitier and more flocculent than 1056. SLightly nutty, soft, clean, with a slightly tart finish. Ferment at warmer temperatures to accentuate hop character with intense fruitiness, or ferment cool for clean, light citrus character. Expect good attenuation, but this will vary with grist, mash, and other wort characteristics. Reliably flocculent, producing bright beer without filtration.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Pale Ale, American Strong Pale Ale, American Amber Ale, American Brown Ale, American IPA, Imperial IPA, American Barleywine, American Stout, Porter, Cream Ale, Strong Scotch Ale, Irish Ale, Imperial Stout, other strong Ales, Christmas/Winter Ale, Spice/Herb/Vegetable Ale, Smoked Ale, Wood-Aged Ale, Fruit Ale

RECIPE.NAME: Dry Stout - All Grain

STYLE.NAME: Dry Stout
STYLE.NOTES: Famous Irish Stout. Dry, roasted, almost coffee like flavor. Often soured with pasteurized sour beer. Full body perception due to flaked barley, though starting gravity may be low. Dry roasted flavor.

HOP.NAME: Goldings, East Kent
HOP.NOTES: Great all purpose UK hop for ales, stouts, porters

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt (2 row) UK
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: All purpose base malt for English styles

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Barley, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body to porters and stouts, must be mashed

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Black Barley
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unmalted roasted barley for stouts, porters

MISC.NAME: Irish Moss
MISC.NOTES: Used as a clarifying agent during the last few minutes of the boil

YEAST.NAME: Irish Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Dry, fruity flavor characteristic of stouts. Full bodied, dry, clean flavor.

WATER.NAME: Burton on Trent, UK
WATER.NOTES: Use for distinctive pale ales strongly hopped. Very hard water accentuates the hops flavor. Example: Bass Ale

RECIPE.TASTE_NOTES: Nice dry Irish stout with a warm body but low starting gravity much like the famous drafts.

HOP.NOTES: Medium-strong, woody with evergreen and mint overtones.
